div.p: COMPOSED for the Schollars of the Free-schoole of Hadleigh in Suffolke.
And acted by them on Shrouetuesday, being the sixt of February, 1626.

div.head: To my singular honest Stationer, Mr. Robert Mylbourne, at his shop in decimo sexto, by the south doore of Pauls.
div.p:
AS you are a true Booke-seller, you must approue your selfe a true Booke-restorer: and therfore by booke or by crooke, see that you send backe my Book. And yet not my Booke. For it was but a borrowed Booke, for which my promise and credit lye in mortgage to the Author, the Schoolemaster of Hadley, who with some difficulty lent it me, hauing no other coppy of this English Lesson which. he prepared for a By-exercise for his schollars at the last Carneual. He told me that hee huddled it vp in hast, and that it being onely an essay of his owne faculty, and of the actiuity of his tenderlings, he was loath it should come vnder
any other eye, then of those Parents and domestique friends who fauourably beheld it, when it was represented by the children. And therefore, I must be, and am tender of suffering it to wander I know not whither, by the out let of your friends hand: whom as I know not, so I cannot challenge of any trust; but require restitution of you, as the Author doth of me. So, expecting without delay, the returne of this bird into the cage, I end with a threat, that if you faile, you must looke to haue this Comedy turned into a Tragedy, and, for detaining this booke, to haue your name set on the backe side of my booke. Whereto I adde yet a deeper curse, that next time you meet with good fellowes in Epping Forrest, you may not be so happy, as to feed them with nuts in stead of money.

closer.signed: Yours as you shall deserue the endorsement of this my letter. E. W.

div.head: The aforesaid Stationers answer.

opener.salute: LOuing, Challenging, Threatning friend, E. W.

div.p:
I pray you extend your loue so farre to your friend, and your friends friend, as to thinke that neither the first will defraud you of your borrowed Booke, nor the second expose the Author to any inconuenience. The truth is my friend, vpon the sight of this Morall, Scholasticall, Theatricall Treatise, protested that the Author should receiue much right in being thus wronged; and vpon sufficient bond vndertooke to saue me harmelesse if I made it more publique then euer was intended. And withall hee armed me with a legall defence, that, if I restored tenne sold for the principall, the Author (notwithstanding his modesty) could frame no iust quarrell against me or you at the barre of iustice
or reputation. Accordingly he incouraged me (if Master Schoolemaster of Hadley should schoole you for promise-breach) to stop his mouth with a dozen of chicken hatcht vnder his owne henne.
I pray you therefore in stead of his owne single written Coppy, coppy him with this packet of his owne mettall stamped and multiplied by the Printers Alchimy.

The worst I heare, is, that hee will complaine to Apollo of me that I haue proclaimed abroad his priuate Shrouing. For which I haue a defence from the Authors owne penne, that Apollos solemne visitation begins with Proclamation. Act. 1. Scen. ultima And, I trow Proclamations are intended to flye abroad in print. So in hope that I shall receiue, if not thanks, yet pardon from him. I rather take, then begge, leaue to remaine still

closer.signed: Yours no lesse by this, R. M.
closer.dateline: London, Aprill, 25. 1627. From the smell volume of my shop, where the south winde blowes into Pauls.

div.head: Apollo Shrouing.
Composed for the Schollars of the Free-schoole of Hadleigh in Suffolke. And acted by them on Shrouetuesday, being the 6. of February, 1626.

list.head: Dramatis personae.
list.label: Musaeus, Apollos Priest & Iudge.
Clio a Muse, his assistant.
Euterpe a Muse, another assistant.
Lawriger his Verger.
Drudo his Booke-bearer.
Preco the Cryer.
Thuriger the Sexton of Apolloes Temple.
Scopas the Sextons boy.
Philoponus a diligent student.
Amphibius a perplexed scholler.
Nouice a young fresh schollar.
Rowland Retro an hasty non-proficient.
Geron an old man, his mournful father.
Ludio a truantly schooleboy.
Siren a sea nimph, messenger from Queene Hedone.
Captaine Complement a teacher of gestures and fashions.
Iacke implement his Page.
Misse Indulgence Gingle, a cockering Mother.
Iohn Gingler sonne a disciple of Captain: Complements.
Iugge Rubbish maid-seruant to Mistrisse Gingle.
Slim Slugge, a lazy droane.
Epilogue.

sp.speaker: Prologus.
sp.p: SI quisquam est, qui placere se studeat bonis Quam plurimis, et minime multos laedere, In his pocta hic nomen profitetur suum.

sp.speaker: Lala.
sp.p: What? shall wee haue Latine againe? Master Prologue yongster. I pRay you goe to the Vniuersity, and set vp your Stage there.

sp.speaker: Prol.
sp.p: What, Mistresse Lala Spinster? content yourselfe, I now repeat that which is past, I doe not represent that which is present.

sp.speaker: Lala.
sp.p: I pray you then tell vs so much in honest English.

sp.speaker: Prol
sp.p: I will, for your sake.

sp.speaker: Lala.
sp.l: For mine? nay, for euery shee,
Whom here you see:
And for our honest neighbours, many a good man that neuer
Was infected with this rauing latine euer.

sp.speaker: Prol.
sp.p: Keepe silence, thou party-coloured chattering Mappy.

sp.speaker: Lala.
sp.p: Then speake sence, thou iabbering al-blacke Iackdaw, with a greene coxcombe.

sp.speaker: Prol.
sp.p: Good men, good wiues, good friends, good maids, good boyes.

sp.speaker: Lala.
sp.p: I marry, this tasts for my stomacke, I'me in the number of the fourth ranke.

sp.speaker: Prol.
sp.p: Who meete, to see, and heare our childish toyes.

sp.speaker: Lala.
sp.p: Well said, such easie drops sinke well into our braines.

sp.speaker: Prol.
sp.p: Of late ye know, if ye haue not mistooke vs.

sp.speaker: Lala.
sp.p: I doe not mistake you now, you take vs very well with your plaine dealing English Poetry.

sp.speaker: Prol.
sp.p: Wee acted Comicke Terence his Eunuchus.

div.stage: He displaies the outer end of the Banner wherin is the name of Eunuchus.

sp.speaker: Lala.
sp.p: Eunuchus! Out vpon him, and thee too, and all of his kin. I haue heard my brother say, that this same Eunuchus is a man and no man,
The very scorne and hate of women.
I'le be sure, Ile hang, draw and quarter him; and for my part, sir Prologue, She teares the paper.
I had rather ye should beat vs,
Then thus defeat vs,
Rebuke vs,
Then Eunuch vs.

sp.speaker: Prol.
sp.p: For my part dame Lall, I doe but act my part, you must not interrupt me.

sp.speaker: Lala.
sp.p: I will not corrupt you, vnlesse you name that hatefull bilding Iade. O what a queame he hath cast ouer my stomacke with that filthy word.

sp.speaker: Prol.
sp.l: But now we condescend with milde audacity,
In vulgar language vnto low capacity.

sp.speaker: Lala.
sp.p: See you hold on your vulgar tongue, and bring not hither your latine vulgars, and lessons which you haue chanced in the schoole.

sp.speaker: Prol.
sp.l: We come not with old worne common Thais,
by trade the sister of Corinthian Lais.

sp.speaker: Prol.
sp.l: Lais? Thais? Walke where your way is,
And tell vs what this Play is.

sp.speaker: Prol.
sp.p: Nor Parmeno, nor scolding Pythias.

sp.speaker: Lala.
sp.p: Thou pithlesse asse, dost thou tell vs of scolding?

sp.speaker: Prol.
sp.l: This waspe had almost put me out. Out with her.
But in a nearer circle now we walke,
Where with our selues, and of our selues we talke.
Our Schoole imagine here new built and dight,
This Scene our formes, our day this candle light.

sp.speaker: Lala.
sp.p: Sir Prologue, I feare thou talk'st English extrumpery besides thy part, onely to beguile me, I doubt there is Latine in his budget.

sp.speaker: Prol.
sp.p: I auow to thee, iealous Lala, that this same schollers feast is drest in English.

sp.speaker: Lala.
sp.p: I dare not trust you, for you say you are here in the schoole. And you schollers must not speake English in the schoole.

sp.speaker: Prol.
sp.p: We are not now at our taske, but wee haue leaue to play, and we play at our best game.

sp.speaker: Lala.
sp.p: What? Blow point? or Span-counter? or trappe out may hap?
Take heed you grow not Outish.

sp.speaker: Prol.
sp.p: No Tomboy, no. Nor scourge-top, nor Trusse, nor Leape frog, nor Nine holes, nor Mumble the pegge: But a more Noble recreation, where we haue more lookers on, then gamesters.

div.stage: He displayes the Rowle vpon his staffe.

sp.speaker: Lala.
sp.p: What play call you it?

sp.speaker: Prol.
sp.p: Take out thy fescue, and spell here, in this oneleau'd booke. Tell the stitches in this samples of blacke and white.

sp.speaker: Lala.
sp.p: A. P. ap.

sp.speaker: Prol.
sp.p: A. P. ap? Thou fumbling Ape. A. per se, A. P. O. L. pol.

sp.speaker: Lala.
sp.p: A. per se, A. P. O. L. pol, L. O. lo. Apollo. On my maidenhead this is Latine. We shall bee choaked with a dogrell Latine Play for all this.

sp.speaker: Prol.
sp.p: I tell thee, this is Greek, Latine, and English too.

sp.speaker: Lala.
sp.p: This Apollo is he an English man? I'le deale with none but my owne Country-men. I woont haue to doe, so I woont, with these outlandish people that speake gibberish.

sp.speaker: Prol.
sp.p: It is a proper name, it signifies the Lord and Master of the Muses. His Throne and Court here represented is the shoppe and staple of learning.

sp.speaker: Lala.
sp.p: A proper name? As you are a proper man, let none but English wares bee sould in this shop, or else you haue no customer of me.

sp.speaker: Prol.
sp.p: Nay, reade on what followes.

sp.speaker: Lala.
sp.p: S. H. R. O. shro. I'le none of this. What, doe you call vs shroues?

sp.speaker: Prol.
sp.p: Thou art not worthy to goe a shrouing, that canst not spell it.

sp.speaker: Lala.
sp.p: V I. N. G. ving, shrouing I'me glad of that. Now I like this Apollo well: hee'le goe a gossipping with vs. does Apollo come a shrouing to vs, or shall wee goe a shrouing to him?

sp.speaker: Prol.
sp.l: All which we on this Stage shall act or say,
Doth solemnize Apollos shrouing day.
Whilest thus we greete you by our words and pens,
Our sorouing bodeth death to none, but hens.

sp.speaker: Lala.
sp.p: Pennes? hennes? Me thinkes the feathers of hens should not make good pennes. I doe not like the death of hennes. As I'me a true housewife, I wondred what made our henne roost so empty, and see the schollars haue gotten them.

sp.speaker: Prol.
sp.p: I prethy, hold thy peace, thou goest beyond thine office, thou'lt haue the first word and the last too, thou shew'st thy selfe to be a true Lala.
But whil'st I chat with her, the time growes late, I'le sixe this banner at Apollos gate. Exit.

sp.speaker: Lala.
sp.p: As I'me a true woman, I'le trust you slippery schollars no further then I see you. I woont away, till I tast of the first dish of Apollos shrouing seast, and know whether it was an English Cooke that drest it.
I see a blacke coate come in, I'le know whether hee be a true Brittaine.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Ecce vigil nitido patefeci ab ortu
Purpureas aurora fores, et plena rosarum
Atria. Dissugiunt stellae, quarum agmina cogit
Lucifer, & coeli statione nouissimus exit.
Iungere equos Titan velocibus imperat beris.

sp.speaker: Lala.
sp.p: I can hold no longer. False play. I barre your dice. Body o'me, I thought how we should be seru'd.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: What bold Nimph is this, that durst intrude amongst the Muses?

sp.speaker: Lala.
sp.p: O'my life, this is no English. My Mother neuer spoke it. I proclaime to all of my sexe, they haue leaue to depart. I'de rather spinne at home, then heare these Barbarians spout Latine, Vnlesse we had some kinde schollar to tell vs what they say. What a foppery is this, that we must laugh for company, and then aske what we laugh at.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Ignorant suspicious soule, be content, I will bee thine Interpreter.

sp.speaker: Lala.
sp.p: If you doe not interprete to me, I'le make you plumme the play, you shant be able to goe on your part.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Then so.
Now gins the faire dew dabling blushing morne
To open to the earth heauens Easterne gate,
Displaying by degrees the new borne light.
The stars haue trac'd their dance, and vnto night
Now bid good night.
The young daies Centinell the morning slarre
Now driues before him all his glittering flocke,
And bids them rest within the fold vnseene
Till with his whistle Hesper call them forth.
Now Titan vp and ready cals aloud,
And bids the rowling houres bestirre them quicke
And harnesse vp his prauncing foaming steeds
To hurry out the sunnes bright Charriot.
O now I heare their trampling feet approach:
Now now I see that glorious lampe to dart
His nearer beames, and all bepaint with gold
The ouer peeping tops of highest hils.

sp.speaker: Lala.
sp.p: Trust you vpon your word? Did not you promise to interprate? Heer's linsey-woolsey fustian, where euery English thread is ouer-cast with a thicke woolen woofe of strange words, which haue so deepe a nappe, that the plaine ground cannot be seene. I pray you what haue you said all this while?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: I haue said but one word, Lucescit, It is morning.

sp.speaker: Lala.
sp.p: And could you not haue told mee that in one word, by bidding me good morrow?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: I giue no morrow vnto thee, but to the Muses, and my selfe.

sp.speaker: Lala.
sp.p: I haue as good part it h day light, as the best mincing Muse o' them all.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Welcome faire light, most welcome vnto mee, When these thy beames reflect vpon my booke.

sp.speaker: Lala.
sp.p: Now I vnderstand you better. I hope hee'le mend.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: O how it ioyes my watchfull eyes and heart, To crop the first fruits of the virgin morne.

sp.speaker: Lal.
sp.p: Crop the first fruits of Virgins? I'le take heed of him.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: And spend that pretious stocke of common light
Vpon this Authors lines, and such bookeware.
The morning is the Muses gainest friend.

sp.speaker: Lala.
sp.p: Surely this schollar loues to come first to schoole.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: O how my blood doth warmely sweetly thrill,
My sences luld, my heart inwrapt with ioy,
To see these plaines, this faire two-headed hill,
Those bowers, these towers, those winding bankes,
These shady laurels, and that Temple gate
The seat, the throne, the nest, the rest, the schoole
Of great Apollo, and his darlings nine.

sp.speaker: Lala.
sp.p: Well, I see now it will bee English. It shall goe hard but I'le get a part amongst them. I'le into the tyreing house, and scamble and rangle for a mans part. Why should not women act men, as well as boyes act women? I will weare the breeches, so I will. Exit.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: NO Court of King, no Pallace stately rich,
Though proud of marble feet & guilded head
Can outbid these for true and sweet content.
Let others grouell and imbrace the earth,
(The earth the whole worlds basest sediment)
Let them there digge their mothers bowels out,
And thence take gold (the earths worst excrement)
Let muddy mindes board vp, and hugge, and hide,
And sit vpon the egges of auarice:
Thence hatching vipers of their stinging cares.
Let others sell their liues away in sport,
Or play the Parasites in fickle Court.
Let others swell with greatnesse, burst with pride.
And others luske and snort in lazy sleepe,
Or drench and soake themselues in Bacchus sudds,
Or wallow in the mire of pleasures lewd:
These seats, these bowers, are to Philoponus
True pleasure, riches, honour, kingdome, rest.
But now faire Phoebus with his rising raies
Strikes on his owne bright Temples battlements,
The watchword for the daily sacrifice.
The sunnes first heate, that warmes this temples top,
Cals for the Altar to be warme below.
Now now Musaeus his obseruant Priest
With other seruiters bestirre them quicke
To feed that neuer-ceasing sacred fire.
My part must be in that deuotion,
To take from thence a blessing for the day.
Our actions hence haue their prosperity,
By timely worshipping the deity.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p:
WHat is he gone? I so. He keepes out wonted time, and now is well imployed in doing sacred homage to Apollo. There layes he the foundation of his studious diligence. There sore he misses me, and sayes vnto himselfe. Where is my Amphibius? Why keepes he not his accuostomed houre? What, shall I after Philoponus into the temple?
'Tis with the latest now. And (to confesse the truth) alas I dare not there appeare to present my selfe before Apollos Altar. Nor haue I now the boldnesse to looke my deare Philoponus in the face. His setled countenance and graue gesture giue a cheeke vnto my leuity. His very silence reades vnto mee a lecture of reprehension. My passions so deepe inthrald another way, bid mee now rather to withdraw from such society, and hide my selfe in shades and groues, and solitude.

Alas Amphibius, though hauing tide himselfe to the mast of safety by the bonds of temperance, yet breaketh loose, and leapes into the sea of danger. Alas hee cannot hold. This Sirens song is so attractiue. I yeeld, I come And yet how can I? shall I runne away from the worthy trade whereto I am bound apprentise? My name is inrold in Apollos register, and shall I rase it out, and be reckoned among the fugitiues and renegados? Not so. And yet and yet it will be so. O how my very booke seemes now a burthen vnto me, and that which heretofore did eleuate my soule, and giue it wings to flye aloft, sweet contemplation of nature and of arts, that now alas layes on me the heauy load of vpbraiding, I flye, I flye, I hast into the by waies of these thickest groues
What darke some caue will giue me shelter, and hide me from the light of mortall eyes, and of the immortall eye of this world the all-vuiewing Phoebus.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: ANd now me thinkes my spirits lighter are,
My soule more cleare, my wits more actiue far
Since I receiu'd from graue Musaeus hand
Apollos benediction for this day.
sp.p: But where is my Amphibius? hee promised to ouertake me at this morning sacrifice. I hasted not, I did protract till Phoebus (whose swift Chariot no hand can stay) by his visible messenger call'd for our common duty and deuotion.

What will he thus leaue me alone? And yet euen thus alone I am not. Nunquam minus solus quam cum solus. My bookes and meditations are my companions, that neuer faile me. With me they walke and talke, with them I rest at home: and other while when I trauell abroad and conuerse with contemplation, how short and easie are the wayes? yea, and how safe too? I can feare no the eues: the Muses are my guard. And in very truth, what can the eues rob me of? My purse is light, and so my heart. My true riches treasured vp in the cabinet of this breast, no lurching hand by stealth, no robbing rouer by force can seise vpon. My Father hath no land to leaue me. I thinke his meane estate is the better meanes of my happinesse. This education which he affoords me, I take for a more goodly and durable inheritance, then if he could haue left mee thousands of stockes and acres, without any bringing vp in qualitie other then the gentle vanities of the times.
I enuy not our spruce gallant Gingle, that now forsooth scornes to be our schoole-fellow any longer. Our sable robe is too homely for such gaudy butterflies.
But ho Philoponus whither dost thou range? These flyes not worth the gazing on would seduce me out of my way. Away ye flutering mothes that fain would eate holes in the Muses robes.

Come wise Philosophers, come soule-plying Orators. Nay to you I come; ye are my home, the true centre whereon my circling thoughts doe rest. O mellifluous Tully. O streaming ouerflowing Ouid. O Maiestique Virgil. Graue Quintillian. Sententious Isocrates. Vertuous Seneca Plentifull Plutarch. Profound Aristotle. Diuine Plato. My solace, my guides, my instructers. O how your words distill into my thirsting soule, like to immortalizing Nectar.
Where left we last, sweet numbersome Isocrates?
O here, where thy lampe burneth bright.
{non-Roman} {non-Roman} {non-Roman}. Isocrat ad Demonic.

This rule he deliuers, Thinke not to walke vnseene when thou goest about any wickednesse. For, though no man ouerspye thee, thine owne conscience keepes watch ouer thee. O the diuine power of vnbred conscience? Sutable to this is that of Seneca. Quid prodest non habere conscium habenti conscientiam? When Amphibius and I discoursed on this point at our priuate reading of Seneca, I remember how affectionately he would take the booke into his bosome, and hugge it, and protest that this one sentence is able to make vs honest men. I will seeke him out, that we may mutually kindle the sparkes of conscience in our breasts, Exit.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: COme away, come away.
Now cleerely shines our shrouing day.
Now are we fresher then in May,
Come, come away, our worke is play.

sp.speaker: Drud.
sp.l: Apollos solemne shrouing feast,
Inuiteth all from cast to west:
Come away, come make no slay,
No Muses friend can say vs nay.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.l: Apollos yeerely visitation
You know begins with Proclamation,
Come mouthing Praeco, cleare thy threate,
And chant the law in twanging note.

sp.speaker: Preco.
sp.p: O yez.

sp.speaker: Dru.
sp.p: He may cry O yez till his belly burst. But, for ought I see, heer's no body to heare him.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.p: No body? That's none of our fault. All may come if they will, Apollo keepes open sessions. Looke Praeco, canst thou see no audience?

sp.speaker: Preco.
sp.p: Nor man, nor mouse.

sp.speaker: Dru.
sp.p: If I see any body, I would I were the Muses Tankard-bearer.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.p: That's a punishment would noe neere to begger you. For I am sure you would be licking vp the Castalian drops that fall from the Muses tankard, and that would make you turne ryming Poet.

sp.speaker: Drud.
sp.p:
I wish I had no better fortune, then to be a pretty water Poet with a high forehead like I. T. that acts the swanne by the bankes of Thames in England.
I curs'd my selfe happily.

sp.speaker: Preco.
sp.p: What is that acting the swanne?

sp.speaker: Drud.
sp.p: I meane the swannes, or gooses broad paddle feete, the naturall prime patterne of the artificiall oare.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.p: O que, I haue him. He meanes the easie smooth volluminous vntaught Poet, that will row you ouer the Thames in rime, euery stroake of his oare cuts out the capering feet of his verses.

sp.speaker: Drud.
sp.p: Would we had him in Parnassus. Hee would stroake our Mistresses the Muses gently with his oare, and make their worships very merry, with his paper Wherry.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.p: Paper Wherry? you meane by a metaphor, that his papers and verses carry a mans attention as smooth as a wherry.

sp.speaker: Drud.
sp.p: No, I meane his sayling in a Paper Boate, and poetising vpon that and other his owne aduentures.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.p: Hee shall haue my voice to be admitted into the third forme of the Vshers part in Parnassus schoole, if he will lay his claime for it in solemne session.

sp.speaker: Preco.
sp.l: I'le register his name with a witnesse,
If he bring euidence of his fitnesse.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.p: This Poeticall Boat hath made vs saile out of our way. Drudo looke downe there betweene the Temple and the hill, see if you spye any body. And you Praeco, put on you spectacles, and looke into the Groue.

sp.speaker: Drud.
sp.p: Neither bird nor feather.

sp.speaker: Preco.
sp.p: Neither fish nor finne.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.p: We shall forfeit our liberties, if wee can get no audience to listen to our Proclamation. Praeco, vp that bancke, nay mount vp that tree.

sp.speaker: Dru.
sp.p: It is more wholesome mounting that one tree, then some other three trees, compact in a Greeke Pee.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.p: Seest thou any body now?

sp.speaker: Preco.
sp.p: Abundance. O multitude! O variety!

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.p: What be they? discouer them to vs.

sp.speaker: Preco.
sp.p: Men. Boyes.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.p: Who else?

sp.speaker: Preco.
sp.p: Item there be others, shall I discouer them too?

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.p: Why not?

sp.speaker: Preco.
sp.p: I am too bashfull to vncouer them. They are women.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.p: On pratling Preco.

sp.speaker: Preco.
sp.p: Men, women, yong, old, blacke, white, blew, sitting, standing, looking, laughing.

sp.speaker: Drud.
sp.p: Whence thinkest thou come they, and what would they?

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.p: No doubt they come a shrouing to Apollo. If the Muses haue not prouided for their pallat, what shall we doe?

sp.speaker: Drud.
sp.p: It is hard to dresse a shRouing dish to please so many seuerall tasts. They must be content to take such as they finde or bring, like good gossips.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.p: Well sir Preco, for the first seruice, let them heare the Proclamation. Begin.

sp.speaker: Preco.
sp.p: O yez, O yez, O yez.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.p: All manner of schollars and students

sp.speaker: Preco.
sp.p: All manner of schollars and students

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.p: With their Reteiners

sp.speaker: Preco.
sp.p:
With their Reteiners and appurtenances that hold or pretend to hold‑ in Capite‑ any learning, art or science‑ of the grand Lord our soueraigne Apollo‑ or of the meane Land. Ladies‑ the nine sister Muses‑ or of any of them‑ Let them appeare this day in the
afternoone‑ at the great lowrell on the westerne top of Parnassus‑ there to doe their homage suite and seruice‑ and to giue account to our said Lord Apollo‑ or to his high steward Muss us‑ of the expence of their time‑ in their seuerall trades‑ and mysteries‑ of the Muses‑ also there and then‑ vpon the oath of homagers‑ strict inquiry and search is to bee made‑ concerning all incroachments‑ intrusions‑ and Nuissances‑ done or suffered to be done‑ vpon the inheritance‑ rites and royalties‑ pertaining to the manner of Parnassus‑ All that will accuse, shall bee heard‑ and all that will answer‑ shall haue liberty‑ of defence‑ by themselues‑ or by their counsaile‑ learned in the Muses lawes.
Keepe Apollos peace, and then he end the Muses prosper you.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.p: Come downe now Praeco from your chaire of stare, and walke with vs mortals here below.

sp.speaker: Drud.
sp.p: lauriger thinke you that any of those, whom Praeco oueruiewed, will lay in any action at Apollos Court to day?

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.p: Why not? perhaps some of them hold for life some paper Tenement belonging to Apollos Manner. And thereupon may craue admittance to it Others vpon their experience may informe Apollos iury what wast hath beene made of the trees in Parnassus groue with cropping off laurell garlands to adorn the light head of euery ballad belching Poet. Or what delapidations haue in processe of time growne vpon the Muses cells. So that Boreas whistles euerloud in their eares when they are retired to contemplation.

sp.speaker: Drud.
sp.p: These and all other informations shall be surely heard. We know that is our Lord Apollos expresse mandate.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.p: Now returne wee vp the Mount, and acquaint Musaeus what we haue done. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: REnowned Father of fashions, Count of courtesies, Marquesse of moderne motions, Duke of debonaire deportments, Chiefe Iustice of gesticulations.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Goe on with the Alphabet of my Titles. Comptroller.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: I haue it, Comptroller of Conges, Compactor of Cringes, Fea● Framer of fustian phrases.

sp.speaker: Nou.
sp.p: O wonderfull: this is a braue man. Wee haue no such dainty words in our schoole.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: Dainty? I tell thee, Nouice, we haue store of this plumporridge at our house euery day. (little else.)

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Sirra, you forget the Titles giuen mee by the great Mogull, when I went Ambassadour to him from the King of Calecut, a golden trumpet sounded them in the Persian language.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: That trumpet could speake Persian well, I can hardly hit vpon them in the originall. Varletto, polmone, manigoldo.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: You masque vnknowne, vnseene. Descend I say to the apprehension of the base vulgar. Giue vs them in translation.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p:
Indoctrinate of yong Nobility. Accomplisher of Kings Courts, chiefe engineer of cap and knee. clock-keeper of nodde and shrugge, and finally, ingrosser of all saylable,
auaileable adresses, garbs, faces, graces in all places.

sp.speaker: Nou
sp.p: Yet gooder and gooder. O admirable! This man is for vs to the heauens.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: It is well, somewhat toward the superlatiue of my worth and profession But Imp. I like not that word finally. When you rehearse me before the Lady Muses, they will thinke wee are at the wall, that thou hast told all my vertues, and offices. I tell thee, not thou, nor the loud long tongue blabbe fame, can giue the inuentary of my perfections. Think'st thou with the small wherry boate of thy short memory, to arriue at the Terra incognita of the vertues and indowments of mighty Captaine Complement?

sp.speaker: Nou.
sp.p: O eloquence. I see now that Tully and Ouid are but course ware.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: I tell thee, and thou shalt finde, that tittle tattle Tully is but browne bread, if hee be laid neere our Marchpane.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Ergo therefore my nimble Imp. take away that padlocke finally, and in stead of the aforesaid, adde to the fagge end of my Catalogue, that endlesse chaine which the vulgar Grammarians call et caetera.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: Indeed Master I haue heard you say, that you would haue your title like the great Westerne Monarches title, with a long taile behinde it.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: True: And therefore you know, the motto which I subscribe in banner is plus vltra.

sp.speaker: Nou.
sp.p: My sweet friend, Master Implement, you told mee that you would speake—

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: I marry, and so I doe.

sp.speaker: Nou.
sp.p: For me to the mighty man. All you haue yet said to him, is but in the vocatiue case. And that case makes no sentence, as I haue learn'd when I was in the second forme. You know I gaue you.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: What did you giue me? Nothing but a dozen of rotten silke points. You must tagge them better ere I the vp your request.

sp.speaker: Nou.
sp.p: I le steale my mothers Peacocke, and bring it you.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: A Peacocke? That's well. You may make vs latter by it; but you cannot make vs prouder.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: What talke you of a Peacocke?

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: Sir, this yong gentleman presents you with a Peacocke. It ha's a tayle. he has a small request to your worship.

sp.speaker: Nou.
sp.p: I dare as well hee hang'd as steale the Peacocke. My mother loues it so well, and feeds it euery day, and pricks the feathers of it in her sanne.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Where is this Peacocke?

sp.speaker: Nou.
sp.p: What shall I dee? I haue none.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: I mistooke a Peacocke for a Woodcocke.

sp.speaker: Nou.
sp.p: I haue neuer a Woodcocke neither.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: Sir he would faine present you with a Woodcocke euery day. His suit is to be your schollar for an houre in a day. He would dedicate himselfe to fine fashions and quaint quallicoms.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: What Nobility? What atchieuements imbolden him to obtrude vpon vs with such a request? An houre in a day? I tell thee, yong chicken, great Princes haue not made such a motion vnto me without an Ambassadour, and a present of a gold chaine, or diamond ring, or some such trifle.

sp.speaker: Nou.
sp.p: Woe's me! Alas. I haue no hope now, I thinke I must eene returne to my old trade againe, & repeate In noua sert animus, and Tityre tu patulae. O sweet Imp. be my faithfull Implement to your Master. I'le doe any thing for thee, or for any of thy kin.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: Will you steale mee your fathers dagger with the siluer hast?

sp.speaker: Nou.
sp.p: And my mothers siluer bodkin too.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: They shall pricke forward thy cause. I gallop to saue thy life. I will begge a pardon for thee of this Iudge. Relent heroicke spirit, relent. For my sake entertaine Master Nouice into your schoole.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Thou knowest our schoole is throng'd. My hands are full. The truth is, my vertuous facultie, ioyned with a strange dexterity, is so attractiue, that I haue schollars come flocking vnto me, not onely from the Theater and Venus Court, but also from Apollos seminarie. I swel, I swel with the stuffings of the Grammar brood.

sp.speaker: Imp
sp.p: I am one of those that lest the fescue trade, to page it thus in state.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Nay, Logique and Philosophy doth often breake vp shop, and come to set vp at my stall.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: Indeed Master of late we haue had very good doings. The Vsher of our schoole has had for fees of yong gentlemen at their entrance, aboue an hundred crownes within this 12. moneths, besides his yearely stipend.

sp.speaker: Nou
sp.p: I'le begge hard, but I'le get a crowne of my Mother, and twelue pence for thee honest Iacke Implement.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: As for money for stipend or entrance, I doe not much stand vpon it, neither would I take any, but that I will not imbase my faculty?.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: Indeed Master, if you should not take some faire see, the gentlemen would not thinke it such a reputation to be your Prentises.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Truely the more cost, the more worship. A wise saying. Write you that in your table booke Master Nouice vpon my authority.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p:
And their Parents would scorne our ware, and say
it were like stinking fish it hend of a market.

sp.speaker: Nou.
sp.p: Againe for me good Imp.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: I pray you sir let him be admitted. Hee'le be content to stand next the doore of our schoole. I warrant you sir, hee'le be fed fat for a whole yeere, with two or three of the easiest plaine trickes, of circling the hat, or the gambrell i'th hammes, the man i'th toe, and the gridiron i'th forehead. Hee'le bee pleased with these till hee can come to higher points of the Retort, the Rebuffe, the Catastrophe, the Antistropho.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: I could bee content to inroll him in our petty forme, but that I doubt some exceptions will be taken at the confluence of so many of that tribe, to our part. Master Philoponus a sowre stoicall schollar, told me to my teeth, that Apollo should bee complained vnto, and I accused of robbery, for stealing away his best hopes.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: Sir, I see no reason but you may entertaine him as well as another. One stone more will not make the boate sinke.
One kernell more put in the sacke
Will not breake the Mrs backe.

sp.speaker: Nou.
sp.p: Good sir consider of me. Though I be not borne to so much land as master Gingle my forme-fellow, yet I shall learne by trickes as well as he. There is Mumble and Tristram, Trump, and Iobbart, and nimble Nichol. I see not, but I may leaue the satchell as well as they, and turne fine gentleman.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p:
Indeed they haue profited very well with vs. For they haue torne out the leaues of all their bookes to light tobacco pipes, and they can infume, & effame, and resume with gentle postures Maister Nimble can at one time, and wah one hand put off his hat
with his right hand in due circumference, and brandish a battoon in's left hand, and sucke a fuming tobacco pipe in's mouth without any hand, all at once.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: They say the old gray beard Mus●us sets vp inquisition, and ●at Apollo keeps Court to day. My sweet Siren sent me word this morning, that I know not how many of vs should be indited for incroaching vpon Apollos liberties.

sp.speaker: Nou.
sp.p: Indeed sir, and't please you, this Philoponus is the best schollar among vs, but he is but a tell tale. There can't one of vs play the tron't, or runne away from schoole for recreation, or so, but presently hee tels Musaeus of it. But I care nor, I had rather sticke to you, and shew Apollo a faire paire of heeles.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: He that stickes to vs must bring some glew: And money is a binder.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Imp. are these yong mans friends rich? Will they lard vs with a fat pension?

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: His father's but a plaine Farmer; but hee's call'd the rich Chuff●. Hee keeps three ploughes, and fourteene yoake of Oxen.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: But will his Oxen giue downe their milke?

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: Faith his mother will stroake hard for it. Shee is a gentlewoman ot'h left side. I haue heard her say, that she would like her sonne better in a scarse and ruffled bootes, then in a gowne with a fardell of bookes.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Well said, enough. You yong man. My seruant hath intreated hard for you. I am content to entertaine you vpon probation.

sp.speaker: Nou.
sp.p: I am ouerioyed, ouerioyed.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Ouerioyed? What a plaine packestaffe phrase is that? you must sublimate your ioy in triumph thus. Hold me downe lest I hit my head against a cloud.

sp.speaker: Nou.
sp.p:
Hold me downe lest I hit my head against a cloud.
O what a braue world is this, all made of oatmeale: I'me now in the way of preferment and gallantry. I'le presently runne to my mother for some cash for my entrance. I'me all now for Maskes, Reuels, Courtship. Poore Apollo farewell. Exit.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Sirra Imp. I honour thee with thankes, a whole bushell, heape measure.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: I, with such light come and huskes am I sed.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: I inrich thee with thankes. Thou hast brought a pretty fat fowle to our net.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: We shall make him a flat foole.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Is not the houre come appointed by mee to giue accesse and interviw to Sir Orgolio?

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: Yes sir, the sunne and clocke sayes so. (And my clocke tels me it is breakefast time. If I could tell where to lunch.)

sp.speaker: Comp
sp.p: Why then Vamos. I set my legges in due array, and march on foot downe to the plaine.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: So you had need. For all your horses haue tenne toes. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Amphibius solus.
sp.p: OR this, or that. This is my duty. So. And though so, yet why not rather that? I o that mine inclination drawes me. O strange Monster, worse then euer nature did bring forth. A man in whom the light of reason shines, to walke in the cloudy night of tempestuous passions, to liue at once in two contrary elements. Glorious Apollo I faine would still remaine chine. And yet. And yet sweet Hedone, I cannot diuorce my selfe from thee.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: PArnassus plaines. I he bankes of Hippocrene, The laurell groue, all walkt, all searcht by mee: and yet I finde him not. O here not hoped, yet now found. Found? Is this he? Is this my Amphibius? Where art thou? Who art thou? Looke vp and shew thy friendly brow. I Hope no distast estrangeth thee from thy Philoponus. What haue we here: The walking ghost of Amphibius? Where is his soule, his life, his looke, his speech?

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: A wandring soule.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Wandring? I know no by way can call thee off from me. These groues, these bankes, and shades, O how oft haue they bin companions and witnesses of our friendship, and discourses of earth, of sea, of starres, of spheares, of motions, of rest, of beasts, of plants, of all Dame natures workes, and wondrous art, by which this All stands thus composed, and framed in most exact proportion. Awake I say, the Muses call vs to our taske.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Worthy Philoponus. I loue thoe. I admire tho●. I enuy thee.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: I know thou canst not enuy me. Thy heart is so generous, and my worth so meane, thou louest mee I know, for the parity of our dispositions and studies.

sp.speaker: Amp
sp.p: Would I were like thee now, as heretofore I haue beene, then should I not bee thus dasht with shame.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: What Amphibius, you are alwaies modest. Hic virtutis color. Blushing is vertues scarlet roabe.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Alas, I am now like a cropped flowre, which fades and hangs the head, I am pulled from the stalke on which I grew.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: What blast hath thunder-strucken thee? Whence art thou fallen?

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: I must vntwist.

sp.speaker: Phil
sp.p: I hope, not from our bond of friendship.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: No: but from my bond of seruice to Apollo.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Thou from Apollo? First may the stars be pluckt from heauen. Why but how?

sp.speaker: Amp
sp.p: In a word, I am turn'd souldier.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Souldier? Which of the furies pluck't thee from our woonted peace and quiet in Apollos seruice, now to pitch thy tent in Marses field?

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: O how the drummes and trumpets sound alarum. What stroakes, what shreekes, what fierce incounters, wounds and deaths!

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: O Tragedy! What Scene is this? On what Stage dost thou tread?

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Alarme, alarme, to warre. I fight, I fight.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: With whom?

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: I must maintaine the quarrell on both sides.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Both sides? Who are the Cumbattants?

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Amphibius, and Amphibius. Neuer till now a true Amphibius As I am▪ Apollos and thine. I walke and march with thee, I fight vnder the Muses colours against ignorance, idlenesse and voluptuousnesse. But as I am another selfe, my left side walkes another way. O force. O compulsion. I yeeld.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: What force compels?

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Fatis agimur, cedite fatis.

The destinies are powerfull. If the fates say I, who
dares say no?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Our fates? Speake right, and say, our faults. They ouer-rule and ouer-turne vs, when wee are willing to be conquered, and then to colour our follies, wee put on the maske of tragique exclamation vpon our starres, our fates, our crosse inexorable adamantine destinies.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Farre easier is it to mocke my misery then to cure it.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Cure it? I will cure it. Let me feele thy pulse. O what boyling and beating waues of passion! W● thou calme them?

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: O could I! or couldest thou my Esculapius?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Recipe a Biletto or taylors bodkin; make but one oylet hole vnder the left pappe, three inches deepe: your blood would be cooled; and you shall fall into a sweet sleepe, and presently bee transported into the Elisian fields. Probatum est.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Facile est miserum irridere.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Not I, but— you fate mongers teach you this. But in earnest I aduise thee thus. Giue ouer parling and combating: blow away your enemy out of the field with one blast. One word will doe it.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: What potent charme is that? I pray you teach it me.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Onely this stoutly said Nolo.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Oft haue I thought and said it, but another word crowds in withall, and makes a counter charme. Volo.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: What? doe you blow hot and cold at once, at once will and nill?

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Vos testor omnes Calites, hoc quod volo, Me notte.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: O Sir, doe you thinke Medea a fit patterne for you? Haue you no better a Mistresse to instruct your wauering soule, then monstrous Medea?

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Yes, another Mistresse ouer-awes me, more powerfull then that Inchantresse.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Ouer-awes? O faint fondling, not worthy to march vnder the Muses banner, whose Escucheon is Vertue Argent, crowned Or. And the two supporters, winged Victory, and winged all-eyed, all-eared, all-tongued Fame.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: When this all-conquering Queene, sends forth her mandates, alas vertue melts into an aercall contemplation, and fame vanisheth into an empty sound.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: What mandates other then vsurped Tyranny? What conquests other then by voluntary yeelding to false allurements?

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: O valiant Sir, can I, can you, can any mortall wight stand out and rebell when hee is apprehended by this Queenes writ?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: What writ? what arrest? you need not obey it. At least you might lurke and withdraw your selfe, and make them returne a Non est iuuentus:

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: O but these arrests doe not so much command by authority, as conuince & perswade by argument and reason.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Reason? what other reason then vt cum ratione insanias, that you may be reasonably rauing madde?

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Tu si hic esses, aliter sentires, the case would be altered, and you would plead as hard on my side.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Then let all the nine Muses hisse at mee, and banish me out of Apollos schoole.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: The Muses? Apollos schoole? I tell you the arguments by which I am conuinced, are translated out of the Records of the Muses, and cite euery where Apollos Parliaments.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p:
What are these forged patches which plead their workemanship from the Muses loomes? Haue you
bin weauing them in your sequestred studies?

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Alas not mine, but on higher hand hath spunne and twisted them. The Queene her selfe vouchsafed with her owne wit and hand to compose this soueraigne Nepenthe to imbalme my soule in most desirable content. Queene Hedone her selfe wrote this large mellifluous letter to me, poore me. I thought she had not knowne me: but (O generous sweet gratiousnesse) to this meane neglected Amphibius, shee (that high and mighty soueraigne of delights) sent this amiable garland of choysest flowers, culled by her owne delicious hand; that hand, which the chiefest Poets labour to paint cut, and the highest gods affect to kisse.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: O how Pocticall you are growne, and fantasticall? I thinke that paper hath infected you. But by what hand was it conueyed to you?

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: By whom, but by her worthy maide of honour Dame Siren, whose voice with one warble can thaw the most frozen affections

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Nay then I perceiue he is handsomely caught.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: I pray you view these liues. You will confesse they are strong lines.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: I haue heard of strong lines, admited by weake iudgements, and derided by the iudicious.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: I pray you read. Else you robbe me of my defence, and your selfe of care pleasing▪ soule-conquering suauity!

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: To my not so deare, as worthy to be farre dearer, Amphibius the flowre of youth—

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: (Meaning me.)

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Honour and enuy of his ranke.—

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: (Meaning me, very good still)

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Accomplisher of vertues—

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: (O compleate!)

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: In nothing wanting, but that he is indebted,—

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: (Yet she does not arrest me for money debt, No)

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Indebted to himselfe, in infinite summes of most currant delights, ouer churlishly neglected by him.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Had these title beene of my owne deuising, modesty would not haue suffered me, to heare them read. But what Queene Hedone sayes, is a law; and it is a part of my obedience to accept the honour she conferres vpon me by her owne hand. She trusteth no Secretary when she writes to me. I think the Muses will wooe me for copies of this letter, they will imitate it, when they sing hymns in praise of Apollo.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: O forgery O foppery!

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Why? what?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Think'st thou that Queene Hedone wrote this leuer to thee? I thinke she neuer heard of Amphibius.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Why? Am I not in the indorcement? I neuer heard of any other Amphibius. I will be this Amphibius till you finde another Amphibius.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: See how thy good nature is wrought vpon. This inscription is none of Queene Hedones hand. Seest thou the character nothing a kin to the letter within

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Perhaps indorcements and names of note, are written in another hand for excellency. That is the Court stile.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Let me tell thee a short tale. Thou hast heard of Burching-lane in London.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: London? Where's that? In England?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: So. And there are many volumes of Appárell made at large by guesse for no man, and for euery man, for all, whom they may fit, or who will buy them.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: What then? I buy none there.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: An honest rurall guest comming thither, is hailed into a shop, and cared with a suite which though too wide, too long or short, hee's perswaded 'twas made for him and none else, he payes, and goes, and after findes it shrinkes.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: What's this to me?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Yes to thee. Mutato nomine de te Fabula narratur. Thou art this new come guest, gazing on and admiring the varnisht wares, set out in the deceitfull shop of Hedone. She cuts out and tackes together, large declamations in folio. In laudem voluptatis. These shee sends abroad by the end of her Broaker Siren: Who, loaden with these blanke letters, rambles vp & down: and, when she lights vpon any credulous soule, presently she addes an indorcement, and makes the receiuer beleeue that Queene Hedone her selfe doth wooe him. Against the concourse of this solemne day this Siren, houering here for gaine, now seiseth on thee. And thou beleeuest that this paper garment was cut out and sow'd and lac'd for Amphibius. If shee meete with me, verily I shall haue another the same letter, indorced, To her deare, her onely deare Philoponus. Then shall I bee the flowre of youth, and what not?

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Admit sir this, that my name, was put in by the bearer vpon generall instructions onely. Yet the powerfull contents of the letter inforce in themselues the conclusion of my yeelding.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Thy yeelding? And why not mine as well?

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Yes brother, and thine, and anyes else, whose heart is not hewne out of a marble rocke. Mine is of flesh, I call a woman Mother.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p:
I am of the same mould with thee. But I bethinke
my self, Why hath Reason the Scepter in her hand, if rebell Passion may bee suffered to crowd into the Throne.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: True, no Oracle more certaine. But alas. But I know not what within this melting brest cryes out lowder, and sayes, Amphibius, Thou shalt now to this case dispence with those seuere rules.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Where is thy Logique? thy Philosophy? Art thou an Orator to perswade others to that which they know not, and canst thou not perswade thy selfe, in that which thou acknowledgest?

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Nay, the Arguments vsed by Hedone, are not emptily blowne vp with passion, but soundly grounded on Philosophy, Logique and Oratory. S●en told me that her Lady Hedone is neere allyed to Manto, Cassandra, Aspasia, and the ancient Roman Tanaquil. That this Hedone, better then Lesbian Sappho, might pretend to be the tenth Muse.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Why then comes she not now to Apollos Court at this solemne assembly, to lay in her claime for it?

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Siren tells me, she had done so, but that she knew not of the set day, and now resideth in one of the fortunate Ilands in the Atlantique sea farre oft from Thessaly. And besides all this, she is inuited to a feast of foure or fiue gods by Mercury into Ethiopia.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Such draffe of si●ens by thy feast.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: For the cause of her absence I passe not much But I'me sure shee's learned, and deepely read. That shee shewes by the reasons and Authorities heaped in her letter.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: What stout reasons? What authorities?

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Euen those which we read and admire in Apollos schoole. What say you to Tully, Plutarch, Aristotle, Seneca, Socrates, Horace, &c.

sp.speaker: Phil
sp.p: I am sure these affoord impenetrable armor against the assaults of Hedone. And now are they brought on the other side against their wills?

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Reade but this line here in the bottome of the second page. Attend what your 〈◊〉 Tully saith, Dandu● aliquid atat●. Non semper ●ncat ratio, &c.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: This time and place s●s not to examine these particulars. Come lets to the laurell Groue. There will we gage to the bottome this fardell of false wares.

sp.speaker: Ludio.
sp.p: ONe tells me I must study next my heart. That troubles my braine too much. Another tels me 'tis good to eate bread and butter next my heart. That fumes fumes into my head too much. And to say the truth, my stomack is not yet vp. For I'me but new vp my selfe, and I hope that will not be so saucy as to tread on his Masters heeles. But I say still, 'tis best playing next ones heart. That is to mee both study and breakefast. Once againe crosse and pile, handy dandy, which hand will you haue?
sp.stage: He plaies two gamesters, and wrangles.—
sp.p: O for some Companions. O for some good play fellowes! Gingle hee's growne so proud, he tells mee hee's not for boyes play now. And Slug I could not get him vp. I bounc'd with my bag of counters against his doore. And he answered me nothing but whough, pugh: Hee outsnorts nine horses, and outsleepes tenne dormise. I will goe find out Nouice. Hee's a yong fat gosling to pull. Exit.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.p: WHen wee had signified to our Lord Apollo our publishing of his Mandates, he was pleased to say that there was neuer more need of warning a Court, then now, that abuses and vsurpations haue crept into his dominions. And therfore he charged vs that this inquiry should be more strickt then heretofore. Intra● Siren.
But looke you now. There is one of the wormes and catterpillers of our haruest.

I know her, though I neuer saw her before. By her fawning gesture and inchanting wand, shee's that famous infamous Siren, which so troubles and bewilders some of our society. Shee hookes at all shee meetes. It's meruaile if she reach not at me.

sp.speaker: Siren.
sp.l: TO thee, renowned Lauriger,
I come a happy messenger,
From Hedone, Queene Hedone, sweet Hedone,
The Goddesse of delight and pleasure,
The life of life, the worl is best treasure,
Performe what I aduise,
And thou shalt be more wise,
Then all the rest that follow
Your mighty god Apollo.
Apollos taske torments your braines,
Abates your spirits, dries your vaines.
Vaine is your labour little profit,
No quiet by it, no end of it.
O cast away that lawrell bow,
And crowne thy head with roses now,
Now whil'st thy frolicke youth giues leasure
To bath thy selfe in choysest pleasure.
Thy time doth goe,
As riuers flow.
Ere long, you know,
Gray haires will grow.
Then shalt thou sigh, and say with teares,
Why lost I so my youthfull yeares?
My spring is past, yet faine I would,
(But cannot) budde in winters cold.
Come then before age bids good night,
Spend youthfull day in sweet delight.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.p: Is this the lecture you reade to vs? Is this all you can say? A flourishing glosing poeticall Theme, that hath neither truth nor substance in it. An empty sounding painted drumme, fit for children to heare and follow with their rattles and hobby horses. Goe Gill flurt, goe set vp your Pedlars shop in Venus Court. There shall you haue those that will dance to your musicke.

sp.speaker: Siren.
sp.l: No man so learned, wise, or strong,
But may be conquered by my song.

sp.speaker: Lau
sp.p: I can heare thee no longer. Auaunt thou Circe. Think'st thou to transforme mee into a swine? I flye. Exit.

sp.speaker: Siren.
sp.p:
If hee gone? I will not leaue him so. A letter
from the goddesse her selfe may pierce deeper with him, as it did with Amphibius. Exit.

div.head: Actus tertius. Scena prima.
div.stage: Mistresse Indulgence Gingle, Iohn Gingle her sonne, Iugge Rubbish her maide.

sp.speaker: Indul.
sp.p: IVgge Rubbish, what, Iugge Rubbish. Come and bring his girdle.

sp.speaker: Iug.
sp.p: Heere forsooth.

sp.speaker: Indul.
sp.p: Haue you warm'd it?

sp.speaker: Iug.
sp.p: I can finde none but seacole fire to warme it:

sp.speaker: Indul.
sp.p: Out vpon thee slut Seacoale? I cannot abide to haue any of that brimstone fume to come about the body of my childe. Goe kindle some Charcoale, and warme it well on both sides. Exit Iugge.
What Mother can thinke it any paine to bring forth so pretious a fruit? O my liuing walking ioy, thy fathers picture, and thy Mothers selfe, why shouldest thou be weaned from my lappe?

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: Sweet Mother. If I were to chuse a Mother,
Thou and no other
Should be my Mother.

sp.speaker: Indal.
sp.p: Sweet Childe, when thou speakest, mee thinkes the Muses, if there were nine times nine of them, are but Oysterwomen and Kitchinsluffe.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: Honourable Mother Indulgence, I must be no more prentise to Apollos trade. Must I?

sp.speaker: Indul.
sp.p: No my Childe, thou art in a better trade. We are higher flowne now.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p:
I like this new Master better then Musaeus. Wee
haue no terrible scepter shaken ouer vs in the Captaines schoole.

sp.speaker: Indul.
sp.p: Out vpon that bloody butcherly weapon. What a base thing it is, that a man should bee arm'd against children? What naturall Mother can suffer her owne flesh and blood to bee torne by these blacke gown? Canibals? He that rancheth the flesh of my child, had as good kisse—

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: Mother, I haue heard that he was hang'd that inuented burch.

sp.speaker: Indul.
sp.p: I, and he that inuented bookes escaped by burning in the hand. Redit Iugge.

sp.speaker: Iug.
sp.p: I haue almost scorcht my fingers with warming it:

sp.speaker: Indul.
sp.p: Shrinke in while I buckle it, that you may bee gaunt and fine in the wast.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: Mother. When you goe in your coach vp Parnassus hill, I must sit in your lap, must I not? and hold Tisbies left eare in my hand with two fingers thus Must I not? O it is the finest Puppy.

sp.speaker: Indul.
sp.p: I, darling, and hold my fanne in thy other hand, and sometime shake it at the common people when we passe by them.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: Indeed Mother, these are very Gentlemanlike feates. I wonder the Captaine has not read any lecture to me of them.

sp.speaker: Indul.
sp.p: The Captaine is to teach thee more souldierlike trickes. I can teach thee these at home. Why Iugge doe you see how the rose is ruffled on the top of his spur-leather, set it better with your poking finger. (valour.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: He has already taught me one soldierly tricke of

sp.speaker: Indul.
sp.p: What is that my sweet Babby?

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p:
When you are in your Coach, if any horses, though neuer so well bred (except the horses of Apollos owne Chariot) shall presume to take the wall or vpper
hand of any of your Coach-horses, I must straight leape out of the Coach, and with my ponyard stabbe one of those vnciuill horses through both the eares at once.

sp.speaker: Ind.
sp.p: I see Captaine Complement is an excellent Master, he will make my childe be called the sonne of Mars and Bellona. Hee deserues more stipend then I allow him for thee. Why sonne Gingle, this will be an action not onely of valour, but of honour and duty to me.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: If I thus venture my selfe in duty to you, I pray you forget not your duty to me. You know my Father's a man of great worth, and lands, and I am his heire apparant.
I pray you in good company, call not mee plaine sonne Gingle, or sonne Iohn, or so, but Master Iohn, or Master Gingle my sonne, or so. Others will doe mee the more honour for it.

sp.speaker: Ind.
sp.p: True my honourable childe Master Iohn Gingle or so. If thou bee'st vs'd with such respect by mee, how great honour will others yeeld mee that bare thee? But sonne I doubt, if the horses be tall, thou canst not haue them by the eares with thy ponyard. Thou shal▪ haue thy Fathers long guilt Rapier. That will reach them, vnlesse they flye as high as Pegasus.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: O for that Rapier. If I had it, the Captaine would teach me in one day and a halfe, how to weare it, how high the pummell must sit aboue the chape, and how to winde it about when I salute.

sp.speaker: Ind.
sp.p:
I preethy, sweet sonne, let me see thee once act the fine gestures, which the Captaine hath taught you. You doe them by your selfe alone in the chamber, and the doore shut to you. I look't in yesterday at the key-hole, and me thought it did me good to see thee repeat some of them in the presence of a Candlestick,
and Bed-staffe that were set vpon the table.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: Are you auis'd of that Mother? That is a secret, which the Captaine tells mee, that I must shew my feates to none till I am well practised. And another secret, better then that, is, in my priuate practising to set vp imagined spectators for the whetting of my care and diligence. And therefore sometime I set vpon my table, a full auditory of Cushion, Candlestick, slipper, Bellowes, and Chamberpot.

sp.speaker: Ind.
sp.p: See my sonne Master Gingle, see what wrong you doe me then. You will not allow mee that fauour, which you doe to your Bellowes, and that which is below Bellowes.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: As I am a Gentleman Mother, I cannot doe withall as yet. You know when you put me to this mighty Master, you charged mee vpon your blessing to obey him, and follow his instructions, rather then the precepts of Musaeus or Apollo himselfe. But by the next moneth, I thinke the Captaine will giue mee leaue to repeate my postures before you. I will doe your Mothership the fauour to bee in the first forme of my Spectators.

sp.speaker: Ind.
sp.p: Next moneth? I cannot tarry till next day. Hold, heer's a crowne, carry to him for his fauour, to make me a spectator without delay. It may be in your repeating, I shall teach you some gestures that the Captaine thinkes not of.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: But Mother, I hope you will not faile my Master Captaine. You will be a suiter to Apollo for him, that he may continue his schoole of fine feats here neare our doore.

sp.speaker: Ind.
sp.p:
Why childe to that end haue I called to haue my Coach made ready. Apollos great hall is almost a flight shot off on the top of Parnassus, I cannot get vp
thither without my four foure-footed prancers. Iugge bid my Coachman lay the Coach bed backward, for we are to climbe the hill. But I must in to dresse mee better, and set my face in Court fashion. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: VAlerous sir, I pray you cleare your brow. What cloud of discontent enuelops your heroick soule?

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: I tell thee 〈◊〉. I am duloros●, I am fumbled and fuddled, and stu● with two hornes, griefe & anger.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: Hath S●●ned on you?

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Now boy I haue her loue and shall.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: (Well you may, you pay deare for it.) I hope Sir you are not angry with mee sir, your diligent Implement.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: With thee? Thou shrubbe, thou scrubbe. Thou art below my wrath. The thunderbolt of my indignation, where it bolteth forth—

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: (My Masters bolt is soone shot)

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Bestuds the tallest oakes: it strikes not at such dazies as thou art, dandiprat.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: But Master, if you'le giue me leaue, I dare aske who dares make your choller boyle.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Sir boy, I'me angry with my selfe, and with a certaine Knight errant.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p:
Errant? An errant asse he is, that angers you. I'le lay my cap against my dinner (that's oddes against a cheese paring) some Knight has taken the wall of you,
and has challenged you into the field. And now mee thinke, your anger makes you tremble.

sp.speaker: Comp. Imp.
sp.p: learne this of me, no feare, but anger, makes men of valour tremble. For anger is the whetstone of fortitude, as sometime said Sir Harry Tottle, my fellow Knight and Philosopher.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: Woe to that Knight, which coniur'd vp that spright. Your angry spirit will not be coniur'd downe, without blood shed. (The reason is, my Master loues blacke puddings well.) But I pray you Master, what knight? I'le be your second. My keene weapon feedes on bloodshed. But I shall haue the worst in this bloody combat. (For nothing but the pudding skinnes and knotted threeds, will fall to my share.)

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Didst thou marke euen now when Sir Orgolio came to me, desirous to be intoll'd my schollar?

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: I remember you went aside: but I could not perceiue so much as an angry looke betweene you.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: No. He was well pleased: but little to my case. The truth is, for fashions sake, I had him to dinner against to morrow at my lodging. And he.—

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: (Hees inioyned penance by it)

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: And he, like an vnnurtur'd swayne,—

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: Would haue you dine with him.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: NO. No, Imp. The swaine accepted my proffer. Was I so kinde and generous to inuite him, and he be so vnkinde as to come?

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: Indeed that's plaine Country fashion, vnfit for vs.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: I tell thee Imp I hate him for it, and if he come, I'le sauce him for it. He shall dine●s last. I'le temper the sallad with my owne hands.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p:
So you had need, (for we haue no Co●ke to doe it. My Master and I are all the officers i'th house) But Master, is it so hatefull and deadly to accept
a dinner at another mans table? How are you then aliue? Me thinkes the Lords and Knights should haue poysoned you long since.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Thou hast a pestilent crosse witted brain. I thinke thy conceits doe caper the crosse point within thy pericranion. But see how farre thy reach comes short of mine.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: (I me saine to reach farre sometime, else I may starue.)

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Such young cubs as thou, though wily, yet cannot extinguish. I extinguish thus vpon the point. A man may be said to eate anothers meate vpon inuitation, or sans inuitation. Which the vulgar call not inuited▪ I walke the second way. I will not be inuited. My worth, my gentle faculty, My braue profession, They are the Orators, the Messengers, the Sergeants that inuite, and driue, and draw me to the tables of the best.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: I would not be that Porter that should keepe you out (in a cold hungry day when we haue fasted ouer night.)

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: I tell thee, my presence addes honour to the place where I come. Where ere I dine, my vertues pay my share, and where I sit, I leaue behinde me the sweet perfume of courtesie.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: (A sweet perfume quoth he. Hee has forgot at the French Ordinary when two laquies fell out, and one of them drew his ponyard, who was't fell in a swoune and left such a perfume behinde him, that the Chamberlaine spent sixe pence in Frankincense.)

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p:
But hoe, where is this flye? My Imp. I doe vouchsafe to stoope so low as to aske thy counsaile. It inhaunceth my wisedome, to choose such a seruant, as is able to aduise his Master. The wise Commanders in
the warres sometimes listen to the counsell of a common souldier, as Dan Plato saith in his politickes. What sayst thou Imp. What shall I doe to beate this dogge from my doore, it he come to morrow?

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: Let him come, and barke for hunger: the cudgell of my wit shall hang him away

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: So you 〈◊〉 my honour, faithfull Imp. to thee I leaue this 〈◊〉, But 〈◊〉 I would know the medicine whereby thou wouldest purge this distemper out of me.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: I was now tempering and preparing it. List how the hammers heate in the tonge of my brain. Thump. I'le none of that. Thump againe. I like that better.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: I long to see the birth of the childe of thy braine.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: What if you send him word, that this day vpon Apollos call, the whole Academy of vertuous students arriuing here, the Captaine of your Complementall schoole Count Pacheco Giso, takes vp the chiefe Inne in Parnassus.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: O, at the signe of the flying horse Pegasus.

sp.speaker: Imp
sp.p: And there makes his pro●●ast with a Maske, that must last till midnight.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: I preethee doe not hold me till midnight in the vnmasking thy aduise. What's this to mee and Sir Orgolio?

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: And thereupon that the foresaid Don hath ouer intreated your honourable worship to be the Herald and Earle Marshall to set euery guest in● place, and euery did in● ranke.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: That none can doe but I, and those that learne of me.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: Otherwise the Cookes and Sewers will make a ●ay with spi● and chopping kniues: and among the guests there will be a mortall fight for precedency in place.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Well said my boy. I haue it now. Therefore Ergo. the Exclusion is, that, as he would preuent murther, he expect not to haue me stay at home that day.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: That is a charitable exclusion, and tends vnto the preseruation of Apollos peace.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: But how if Sir Orgolio say then hee'le come thither too, and be my shadow there, and play the vnder▪ Marshall at my becke?

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: He cannot be so vnciuill, as to intrude, vnbid, vncooth, vnkist.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: He that would be so vnciuill, as to come inuited, I dare not trust him where he is not called.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: Let him come at his owne perill, yet our house shal be thus acquit of him.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: What if he returne mee word that hee will come and dine with me next day?

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: If so, then rather then faile, I'le blaze it all abroad, that your lodging is set on fire with 〈◊〉 of whole showles and legions of prouision for entertainment.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: That will bee for mine honour, that my great Chamber of entertainement is in combustion with the fumes of my hospitality.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: And for your thrift too, that none shall hereafter thinke to be your guest. (Great Chamber? We haue neuer a ●come bigger then a Coblers stall; and as for fire, it blases no further then a tobaccopipe with vs.)

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: What sayest thou?

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: I say none but the sonne of a Cobler would bee so vncourteous, as to reply against this answer; and none so witlesse, if euer he refined his braines with tobacco

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: O how hast thou raised vp my heauy heart, I warrant I weigh ten pound lighter then I did ere while.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p:
Lighter tenne pound of lead. (For I neuer now him weigh heauy tenne pound of siluer. I thinke the
Faryes runne away with his money. Hee suckes the yong Gentlemens purses, and yet we starue at home.)

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Now is the time that Master Gingle is to meete with vs on Parnassus downes to act his trampling part Uamos. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Lauriger solus.
sp.p: A Man had neede to haue a long forke, to keepe off this Siren. After I had repulsed her insinuating song, she followes me still, and deliuers me a letter, sent from the Lady Hedone (to me, she saies) & shewes a faire indorcement in guilded letters. To the grand supporter of Apollos Court, Lauriger. And so forth as followes in that vn●st title, When I had read the superscription, she by violence would needes imbrace me. I vouchsafed not so much as to open the letter. Wherupon with hatefull heart, and spitefull looke, she vowed reuenge. Now who but she has contriu'd to catch me in a snare. A message is brought to mee by a seeming friend, of proffering a pension from Captaine Complement, to procure a patent from Apollo to hold on his apish trade within these walls.

The Broker told mee, that, of Lauriger, that gold would make me Auriger, that this Captaine fetching ouer diuers of our yonglings, and cheating them of their money, we, by way of reprizall, may take this p●sion, that it is no bribery to receiue it, but an act of iustice: that he that robs a thiefe, hath earned not onely pardon, but also praise.

Now Lauriger summons his wits, and sayes, this is a trap to bring thee in disgrace, and to indanger thy office in Apollos Court. ●ay a straw there Lauriger. Consider that this bragging hobby-horse liues but in al hungry fashion. All he can scratch by cheating, he spends on that witch Siren. He euery quarter to allow a pension of fiue crownes, that can scarce allow himselfe fiue dinners, or an honest flockebed to repose his vaulting bones? Lay another straw th●e, Lauriger, ●t his straw Masse.

sp.speaker: Ludio.
sp.p: I Thinke I rose not on the right side today. I haue rambled vp and downe, and can get no playfellowes.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Nay this snare which they haue laid for me, when me the more to accuse them both anon at Apollos Iudgement seat.

sp.speaker: Lud.
sp.p: Nouice is so taken vp with the Captaine, that hee cannot be for me all this day.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: First I will plead he is a corrupter of youth, and turnes them from humane shape into Baboones.

sp.speaker: Lud.
sp.p: Will no body take pitty on a desolate gamester? Will you play with me? will you?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Secondly, he robbes them of their patrimonies.

sp.speaker: Lud.
sp.p: Come you it'h blew iacket, I'le try with you at this, or that, or these.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Thirdly, he puls away the sweetest nuthings from the Muses breasts.

sp.speaker: Lud.
sp.p: At length well hit, I haue found now. Ho. Sir Lauriger, I challenge you at bull, beare, and horse.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: You will be ho●st at schoole for this. Will not a snatch in the afternoone serue you, and then buckle to your booke againe, but you must lauish out the creame of the morning so prodigally, and hold on thus till noone?

sp.speaker: Lud.
sp.p: I tell thee, I had rather haue this then creame with sugar. I tast my play: all else is vnsauory to me.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: If Mus●us heare of this, Apollos curse will light vpon thee.

sp.speaker: Lud.
sp.p: Apollo is our great Lord. And yet I haue heard that he loues boyes play, and therefore he still continues a boy.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Peace thou babling rauing tongue.

sp.speaker: Lud.
sp.p: What is he else? I am sure he has no beard.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Thou ignorant fondling, that is hieroglificall. His beardlesse flourishing youth, signifies the neuer fading fame which is gotten by his seruice.

sp.speaker: Lud.
sp.p: I, but sir, by your leaue, I haue read, that Apollo was woont to play at Quoits.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: The gods may be said to Quoite when they cast into the lappe of fortune, the lots and fates of mortall men. This is the morall of it.

sp.speaker: Lud.
sp.p: I say Apollo plaid at Quoits, as we doe. And his play-fellow was yong Cyparissus, a boy about my pitch and yeeres, but that he had not so manly a looke, as my selfe, but simpered somewhat womanishly.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Cyparissus that was turned into a Cypresse tree▪

sp.speaker: Lud.
sp.p: Apollo plaid with him, by a good token, their Quoits were knockers, heauier then horse shooes, I think. For the poor boy was brained with one of them.
sp.l: Doth not our Ouid Naso,
That neuer told lye, say so?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: A good token? that's a bad token.

sp.speaker: Lud.
sp.p: O how it grieues my heart to thinke of that honest lad. Ah poore Cyparissus. When I learn'd the lesson in Ouid, I could haue corne that lease out of my book, for very griefe, that such a mischance should fall out at the worthy exercise of Quoiting. Out alas, if my trade did not imploy mee better, I could weepe my pocket full.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: You may take a better lesson thence, then weeping. The meaning of that fable is, that shrode hoyes must beware of spending their time in play, lest some mischiefe befals them: Nay lest Apollo himselfe brain them.

sp.speaker: Lud.
sp.p: You conster false to vs, so you doe.
But I say still,
And so I will.
I gather thence and will lay ods,
That sport and play beseemes the gods.

Else our good Master Apollo would neuer himselfe haue plaid at Quoits in his owne proper person, with a paltry boy, like one of vs. I haue writ this note in the margine of my booke. And I thinke verily if Ouid were aliue againe, and should see my wholsome lines, he would turne them into verse, and adde them to that story.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Ouid had neuer beene so good a Poet, if hee had spent his schoole time idly in play as you doe.

sp.speaker: Lud.
sp.p: Ouid lou'd play well. I haue heard that hee play'd with Corynna.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: How this Lad prates? Ludio I tell thee that was no boyes play.

sp.speaker: Lud.
sp.p: By your leaue sir, Ouid hath honour'd my exercises. He describes in verse our boyes play.
Parna tabella capit ternos vtrinque lapillos,
sp.stage: In queis vicisse est continuasse tuos.
sp.p: Twise three stones, set in a crossed square where he wins the game
That can set his three along in a row,
And that is sippeny morrell, I trow,

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: This boy consters that true, which many a man vnderstood not. Verily thou readest bookes onely where they speake of play.

sp.speaker: Lud.
sp.p: I doe not thinke that if he were here, he would intreat Apollo to play at Quoits with me or checke stone, or spurnepoint.

Good Sir Lauriger, you are better acquainted with Apollo then I. I pray you intreat him to play with mee this great play day. This is his fat remedy at his shrouingfeast they say. I challenge him at all games from blow-point vpward to football, and so on to mumchance, and ticketacke.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: How this boyes fancy makes him saucy. Is it not enough sirra, that you trouble mee thus with your idle chat, but you must be so bold with great Apollo? Hee thinks the gods can injoy no greater blisse then gaming.

sp.speaker: Lud.
sp.p: Sir, doe you heare? rather than sit out, I will give Apollo three of the nine at Ticketacke. I doe not think but I shall take him at a why not euery other game. His mind will be so on the Muses, & vpon his verses.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Apollo and his Musaeus take you too often with a Why-not at-schoole. You know what should follow thereupon. Why-not, &c.

sp.speaker: Lud.
sp.p:
Threaten me not. I tell thee, no torture can make me bate an ace of my play. You would not thinke it, but, as I am true Ludio whensoever I am trembling vnder the hand of the executioner, If I doe but think on my play, then even then, those backe blowes, (which others thinke so rufull) seeme to me nothing,
but threshing hennes at Shrouetide. He that spends his life in play, keepes Shrouetide all the yeere.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Belike you thinke play to be Apollos Shrouetide

sp.speaker: Lud.
sp.p: I that I doe: else why play wee now in honour of Apollo?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: I tell thee this our play if it be weighed right, is three ounces study, and but one ounce play. This fla● of recreation is not kindled without a sparke of diligence. Our playing now is a kind of study, wheras as thy seeming study is nothing but playing or plodding how and where and with whom to play. Thy trade is to be prodigall of (the cheifest riches which is in o● power) time. Thou art a very bankrout of thy owne time: and louest to pull others into the same losses.

sp.speaker: Lud.
sp.p: What speake you of losses? Hee that loseth at one time may winne at another. I can tell you of of young Oleo, he got of Ganeo the Elder, all his points hatband, garters, and a gold ring, and fiue crowns in money; and yet in two houres to see to, see how fortune came with a windlace about againe.

sp.speaker: Lau.
